headline: Tech Weekly: Grok in hot water, app checks if you're dead or alive
summary:
STORY: From Grok getting xAI in trouble to a Chinese app that checks if you're dead or alive, this is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Elon Musk's xAI imposed image editing restrictions on all users of its Grok AI chatbot.

It happened after concerns grew when the service produced sexualized images.

Governments and regulators from Europe and Asia had cracked down on sexually explicit content made by Grok.

xAI said it implemented measures to stop Grok from allowing the editing of images of real people in revealing clothing.

///

U.S President Donald Trump imposed a 25% tariff on certain AI chips under a new national security order.

Products affected include Nvidia's H200 and a rival semiconductor from AMD.

The Trump administration argued the U.S. is too reliant on foreign supply chains which it called a national security risk.

The move targets a number of high-end semiconductors meeting certain performance benchmarks and devices containing them.

///

TSMC profits jumped 35% in the fourth-quarter to $16 billion.

The Taiwanese chip giant scored big from the AI boom and predicted more strong growth this year.

It further said it was working on building fresh U.S. manufacturing capacity.

TSMC - which counts Apple and Nvidia as major customers - announced plans last year to invest $100 billion in the U.S.

////

TikTok will roll out new age-detection technology across Europe in the coming weeks.

The system analyses profile information, posted videos and behavioural signals to predict whether an account may be underage.

TikTok said flagged accounts will be reviewed by specialist moderators rather than automatically banned.

The rollout comes as European authorities look into how platforms verify users' ages under strict data-protection rules.

////

And a new app has gone viral in China which checks if users are still alive.

The app called Sileme in Chinese translates as 'Are you dead?'

It's aimed at people living alone or who live a solitary lifestyle.

It sends automatic notifications to an emergency contact if the user hasn't checked in for consecutive days.

Downloads have surged, leading the firm to introduce a subscription fee and change its name for a global audience.

content.title: Tech Weekly: Grok in hot water, app checks if you're dead or alive
content.summary:
STORY: From Grok getting xAI in trouble to a Chinese app that checks if you're dead or alive, this is Tech Weekly.

:: Tech Weekly

Elon Musk's xAI imposed image editing restrictions on all users of its Grok AI chatbot.

It happened after concerns grew when the service produced sexualized images.

Governments and regulators from Europe and Asia had cracked down on sexually explicit content made by Grok.

xAI said it implemented measures to stop Grok from allowing the editing of images of real people in revealing clothing.

///

U.S President Donald Trump imposed a 25% tariff on certain AI chips under a new national security order.

Products affected include Nvidia's H200 and a rival semiconductor from AMD.

The Trump administration argued the U.S. is too reliant on foreign supply chains which it called a national security risk.

The move targets a number of high-end semiconductors meeting certain performance benchmarks and devices containing them.

///

TSMC profits jumped 35% in the fourth-quarter to $16 billion.

The Taiwanese chip giant scored big from the AI boom and predicted more strong growth this year.

It further said it was working on building fresh U.S. manufacturing capacity.

TSMC - which counts Apple and Nvidia as major customers - announced plans last year to invest $100 billion in the U.S.

////

TikTok will roll out new age-detection technology across Europe in the coming weeks.

The system analyses profile information, posted videos and behavioural signals to predict whether an account may be underage.

TikTok said flagged accounts will be reviewed by specialist moderators rather than automatically banned.

The rollout comes as European authorities look into how platforms verify users' ages under strict data-protection rules.

////

And a new app has gone viral in China which checks if users are still alive.

The app called Sileme in Chinese translates as 'Are you dead?'

It's aimed at people living alone or who live a solitary lifestyle.

It sends automatic notifications to an emergency contact if the user hasn't checked in for consecutive days.

Downloads have surged, leading the firm to introduce a subscription fee and change its name for a global audience.

headline: Nvidia Stock Falls. ‘The Honeymoon Is Over for AI.’
summary: Nvidia  stock was dropping early on Tuesday, hit both by wider market jitters over President Donald Trump’s drive to acquire Greenland and doubts about where the artificial-intelligence boom goes from here.  Nvidia shares were down 2.9% at $180.84 in early trading Tuesday, while the  has fallen 1.1%, and the  has declined 1%.  The move was broadly line with the wider market: Technology stocks are out of favor as investors flee to haven assets such as gold.

headline: AMD Appoints KC McClure to Board of Directors
summary: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Jan. 20, 2026 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- AMD (NASDAQ: AMD) today announced the appointment of KC McClure to its board of directors. McClure most recently served as a senior advisor to Accenture and was previously Chief Financial Officer of Accenture from 2019 to 2024.
